--- title: "Data Viz with Echarts4r" author: "David Munoz Tord" date: "2023-06-25" categories: ["R"] tags: ["dataviz", "interactive plots", "echarts4r"] image: viz.png --- # Goal Learn about *data visualization* and familiarize yourself with some of the basic functions of the {[echarts4r](https://echarts4r.john-coene.com/index.html)}. {[echarts4r](https://echarts4r.john-coene.com/index.html)} is back! And with version 4.5 the new features from version 5 of echarts.js are available now. Moreover, the morphing capabilities of echart.js have been ported to echarts4r as we will show in this post. [Read more about it](https://echarts4r.john-coene.com/) You can morph between plot like this: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(echarts4r) mtcars2 <- mtcars |> head() |> tibble::rownames_to_column("model") e1 <- mtcars2 |> e_charts(model) |> e_bar( carb, universalTransition = TRUE, animationDurationUpdate = 1000L ) e2 <- mtcars2 |> e_charts(model) |> e_pie( carb, universalTransition = TRUE, animationDurationUpdate = 1000L ) cb <- "() => { let x = 0; setInterval(() => { x++ chart.setOption(opts[x % 2], true); }, 3000); }" ``` :::
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} e_morph(e1, e2, callback = cb) ## Warning in e_morph(e1, e2, callback = cb): This is experimental ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
